newsitem.title: CANADA: CWB grain shipment complaint hearing to be Aug 11.
newsitem.headline: CWB grain shipment complaint hearing to be Aug 11.

text.p: A hearing to determine whether Canada's two major railway firms were to blame for a backlog of vessels at Pacific ports earlier this year was set on Wednesday to begin in Saskatoon, Sask., on August 11.
"The Canadian Wheat Board is allowed to submit its complaint and the railways will be cross examined," Canadian Transportation Agency spokesman, Charles Mojsej said.

The CTA is a federal, quasi-judicial tribunal that rules on transportation disputes. The CWB faces more than C$15 million in demurrage fines after ships waited up to 62 days to load grain at Pacific ports between January and March.
In a complaint filed to the CTA in April, the Wheat Board said the railways gave grain movement a low priority.
Canadian National Railway Co and Canadian Pacific unit CP Rail System has asked the CTA to dismiss the CWB's complaint but were their motion was denied.
The railway firms blamed shipment delays on heavy snowfall, extreme cold and equipment failure.
Importers such as Japan expressed concern over the delays.
Two weeks of hearing were scheduled to begin August 11 at Saskatoon's Sheraton Cavalier Hotel, the CTA's Mojsej said.
Forty-one other parties applied to testify, he added.
